prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IRAS12112+0305 CO(2-1) map
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to map the CO(2-1) emission in IRAS 12112+0305 at a resolution of ~0.35 arcsec, and recover all flux at scales up to 4 arcsec.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In order to reduce the data rate we average the windows of the weaker CS(5-4) and CN(2-1) transitions by a factor of 8. The CO(2-1) window was averaged by a factor of 4 because we want to accurately measure the narrow component of the disk too.

In order to spatially and kinematically resolve the outflow, our aim is to detect this peak flux at a 5 sigma level per 0.35'' x 0.35'' beam. This involves dilution factors of (Area outflow)/(ALMA cylce-2 beam) ~20 for our objects Our galaxies are small (< 4'') and the gas is kinematically resolved at scales < 4'' per channel (Fig.2). We therefore prefer observations in C36-4 array, which can provide ~0.35'' resolution and LAS = 4''.

GENERAL SAMPLE: Our sensitivity estimates are set by the estimated amount of cold molecular gas in the outflows. We detect masses of warm molecular H2 gas in the outflows ranging from 4500 - 6500 Msun. Conversion cold-to-hot molecular gas mass for outflows is in range 10^4 - 10^5 (Emonts+2014). This range is in agreement with the ratio measured in the ULIRG IRAS 17208-0014 (~4x10^4; Garcia-Burillo+2015), and it is a lower limit compared to the ratios for the total cold-to-hot molecular gas in galaxies estimated by Dale+2005 and Mazzalay+2013 (~10^5-10^6). We predict to find cold molecular gas masses ~10^8 Msun in the outflows. This is in agreement with cold molecular gas outflows in starburst galaxies and QSOs by Cicone+2014. Taking the standard formula for L'CO and a conservative ratio of L'CO(2-1)/L'CO(1-0) = 0.8 (for sub-thermally excited gas) we predict integrated CO(2-1) intensities ~6.0 Jy km/s (again in agreement with CO(1-0) obervations by Cicone+2014). The FWHM of the velocity dispersion of the outflowing H2 ranges from 150 - 300 km/s (with outflow velocities 250 - 400 km/s). Taking into account the beam dilution factor ~20, we request 5 sigma sensitivities of 0.5 - 0.9 mJy/beam per ~100 km/s channel. This takes on average ~2h per object (including overhead), or 6.6h in total for this project.
TARGET SPECIFIC: IRAS 12112+0305 has a predicted integrated flux of > 5.8 Jy km/s and a FWHM~400 km/s. The outflow is spread across ~2 arcsec^2, or 20 ALMA beams. This results in an expected CO(2-1) peak flux per ALMA beam of 0.8 mJy/beam. We request to detect this at a 5 sigma level across a 100 km/s channel. This requires 2.17h of observing time (including overheads).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IRAS 14348-1447 CO(2-1) map
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to map the CO(2-1) emission in IRAS 14348-1447 at a resolution of ~0.35 arcsec, and recover all flux at scales up to 4 arcsec.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In order to reduce the data rate we average the window of the weaker CS(5-4)transition by a factor of 8. The CO(2-1) window was averaged by a factor of 4 because we want to accurately measure the narrow component of the disk too.

In order to spatially and kinematically resolve the outflow, our aim is to detect this peak flux at a 5 sigma level per 0.35'' x 0.35'' beam. This involves dilution factors of (Area outflow)/(ALMA cylce-2 beam) ~20 for our objects Our galaxies are small (< 4'') and the gas is kinematically resolved at scales < 4'' per channel (Fig.2). We therefore prefer observations in C36-4 array configuration, which can provide ~0.35'' resolution and LAS = 4''.

GENERAL SAMPLE: Our sensitivity estimates are set by the estimated amount of cold molecular gas in the outflows. We detect masses of warm molecular H2 gas in the outflows ranging from 4500 - 6500 Msun. Conversion cold-to-hot molecular gas mass for outflows is in range 10^4 - 10^5 (Emonts+2014). This range is in agreement with the ratio measured in the ULIRG IRAS 17208-0014 (~4x10^4; Garcia-Burillo+2015), and it is a lower limit compared to the ratios for the total cold-to-hot molecular gas in galaxies estimated by Dale+2005 and Mazzalay+2013 (~10^5-10^6). We predict to find cold molecular gas masses ~10^8 Msun in the outflows. This is in agreement with cold molecular gas outflows in starburst galaxies and QSOs by Cicone+2014. Taking the standard formula for L'CO and a conservative ratio of L'CO(2-1)/L'CO(1-0) = 0.8 (for sub-thermally excited gas) we predict integrated CO(2-1) intensities ~6.0 Jy km/s (again in agreement with CO(1-0) obervations by Cicone+2014). The FWHM of the velocity dispersion of the outflowing H2 ranges from 150 - 300 km/s (with outflow velocities 250 - 400 km/s). Taking into account the beam dilution factor ~20, we request 5 sigma sensitivities of 0.5 - 0.9 mJy/beam per ~100 km/s channel. This takes on average ~2h per object (including overhead), or 6.6h in total for this project.
TARGET SPECIFIC: IRAS 14348-1447 has a predicted integrated flux of > 6.3 Jy km/s and a FWHM~600 km/s. The outflow is spread across ~2 arcsec^2, or 20 ALMA beams. This results in an expected CO(2-1) peak flux per ALMA beam of 0.5 mJy/beam. We request to detect this at a 5 sigma level across a 150 km/s channel. This requires 2.51h of observing time (including overheads).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IRAS 22491-1808 CO(2-1) map
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to map the CO(2-1) emission in IRAS 22491-1808 at a resolution of ~0.35 arcsec, and recover all flux at scales up to 4 arcsec.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In order to reduce the data rate we average the window of the weaker CS(5-4) transition by a factor of 8. The CO(2-1) window was averaged by a factor of 4 because we want to accurately measure the narrow component of the disk too.

In order to spatially and kinematically resolve the outflow, our aim is to detect this peak flux at a 5 sigma level per 0.35'' x 0.35'' beam. This involves dilution factors of (Area outflow)/(ALMA cylce-2 beam) ~20 for our objects Our galaxies are small (< 4'') and the gas is kinematically resolved at scales < 4'' per channel (Fig.2). We therefore prefer observations in C36-4 array configuration, which can provide ~0.35'' resolution and LAS = 4''.

GENERAL SAMPLE: Our sensitivity estimates are set by the estimated amount of cold molecular gas in the outflows. We detect masses of warm molecular H2 gas in the outflows ranging from 4500 - 6500 Msun. Conversion cold-to-hot molecular gas mass for outflows is in range 10^4 - 10^5 (Emonts+2014). This range is in agreement with the ratio measured in the ULIRG IRAS 17208-0014 (~4x10^4; Garcia-Burillo+2015), and it is a lower limit compared to the ratios for the total cold-to-hot molecular gas in galaxies estimated by Dale+2005 and Mazzalay+2013 (~10^5-10^6). We predict to find cold molecular gas masses ~10^8 Msun in the outflows. This is in agreement with cold molecular gas outflows in starburst galaxies and QSOs by Cicone+2014. Taking the standard formula for L'CO and a conservative ratio of L'CO(2-1)/L'CO(1-0) = 0.8 (for sub-thermally excited gas) we predict integrated CO(2-1) intensities ~6.0 Jy km/s (again in agreement with CO(1-0) obervations by Cicone+2014). The FWHM of the velocity dispersion of the outflowing H2 ranges from 150 - 300 km/s (with outflow velocities 250 - 400 km/s). Taking into account the beam dilution factor ~20, we request 5 sigma sensitivities of 0.5 - 0.9 mJy/beam per ~100 km/s channel. This takes on average ~2h per object (including overhead), or 6.6h in total for this project.
TARGET SPECIFIC: IRAS 14348-1447 has a predicted integrated flux of > 5.0 Jy km/s and a FWHM~300 km/s. The outflow is spread across ~2 arcsec^2, or 20 ALMA beams. This results in an expected CO(2-1) peak flux per ALMA beam of 0.9 mJy/beam. We request to detect this at a 5 sigma level across a 75 km/s channel. This requires 1.89h of observing time (including overheads).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Using H2 2.12micron integral-field spectroscopy (IFS), we have recently characterized the hot molecular component of massive outflows in local IR bright starbursts. In particular, high velocity (~1000 km/s, FWZI) hot molecular outflows extended over 2-3 kpc regions have been identified in three low-z ultra-luminous infrared galaxies (ULIRGs). Based on our previous works (Emonts+14, Garcia-Burillo+15), we predict total cold molecular outflowing masses of ~10^8 Msun and outflow rates of 15-200 Msun/yr. Here we propose to obtain deep 0.35" CO(2-1) images of these three ULIRGs to: (i) map the massive cold molecular phase of the outflows; (ii) establish the mass loading and momentum boost factors; (iii) and, for the first time, determine the multi-phase (cold/hot molecular and ionized) sub-kpc structure of the outflows in the most extreme local star-forming galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Observatorio de Madrid, Observatorio Astronomico Nacional
Earth and Space Sciences, Chalmers University of Technology
Astrophysics Department, Instituto de Fisica de Cantabria CSIC/UC
IRAM Grenoble, Institute of Millimetric Radioastronomy (IRAM)
Onsala Space Observatory, Chalmers University of Technology
